tit.e: Nashitsubo no Gonin (Five Gentlemen of the Pear Chamber)

sen.j: 梨壺の五人（なしつぼのごにん）とは、天暦5年（951年）村上天皇の命により、平安御所七殿五舎の一つである昭陽舎に置かれた和歌所の寄人である。
sen.e: The "Nashitsubo no Gonin" represents the key members at the waka-dokoro (the imperial bureau of poetry) established within the Shoyosha, which was one of the Shichiden-Gosha (seven residences and five houses for the empress and other concubines), in the Heian Imperial Palace by order of Emperor Murakami in 951.

sen.j: 昭陽舎の庭にはナシの木が植えられていたことから梨壺と呼ばれた。
sen.e: The office was called nashitsubo (which literally means "a palace of pear") because there were pear trees in the garden of the Shoyosha.
The bureau was called Nashitsubo (which literally means "palace of the pear") because of the pear trees that grew in the garden of the Shoyosha.

sen.e: They worked on the decipherment of the oldest anthology of Japanese poetry called "Manyoshu" and the compilation of the "Gosen Wakashu" (Later Selected Collection of Japanese Poetry).
